metadata.titleEn: ChinaHighPM2.5: High-resolution and High-quality Ground-level PM2.5 Dataset for China (2000-2023)
metadata.description:
ChinaHighPM2.5 is one of the series of long-term, full-coverage, high-resolution, and high-quality datasets of ground-level air pollutants for China (i.e., ChinaHighAirPollutants, CHAP). It is generated from the big data (e.g., ground-based measurements, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulations) using artificial intelligence by considering the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution. This is the big data-derived seamless (spatial coverage = 100%) daily, monthly, and yearly 1 km (i.e., D1K, M1K, and Y1K) ground-level PM2.5 dataset in China from 2000 to present. This dataset yields a high quality with a cross-validation coefficient of determination (CV-R2) of 0.92 and a root-mean-square error (RMSE) of 10.76 µg m-3 on a daily basis. Note that this dataset is continuously updated, and if you want to apply for more data or have any questions, please contact me (Email: weijing_rs@163.com; weijing@umd.edu).
The data file contains four codes (Python, Matlab, IDL and R language) nc2geotiff codes for NC to GeoTiff.
metadata.instructions: File Name: The data is stored in the NetCDF file format, and the file name is CHAP_PM2.5_ab_yyyymmdd_V1.nc, where a represents time resolution (D represents daily data, M represents monthly data, Y represents annual data), b represents spatial resolution (1K represents 1km), yyyy represents year, mm represents month, and dd represents day. Data reading method: Python, Matlab, IDL, and other programming methods can be used to convert files from NC to TIF. The data coordinate system is WGS-1984, with a background value of 65535.

literatureList.titleEn: Reconstructing 1-km-resolution high-quality PM2.5 data records from 2000 to 2018 in China: spatiotemporal variations and policy implications
literatureList.referenceEn: Wei, J., Li, Z., Lyapustin, A., Sun, L., Peng, Y., Xue, W., Su, T., & Cribb, M. (2021). Reconstructing 1-km-resolution high-quality PM2.5 data records from 2000 to 2018 in China: spatiotemporal variations and policy implications. Remote Sensing of Environment, 252, 112136. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rse.2020.112136

literatureList.titleEn: Improved 1 km resolution PM2.5 estimates across China using enhanced space-time extremely randomized trees

Improved 1 km resolution PM2.5 estimates across China using enhanced space-time extremely randomized trees. Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics, 20(6), 3273-3289. https://doi.org/10.5194/acp-20-3273-2020

background: Exposure to fine particulate matter (PM2.5) can significantly harm human health and increase the risk of death. Satellite remote sensing allows for generating spatially continuous PM2.5 data, but current datasets have overall low accuracies with coarse spatial resolutions limited by data sources and models. Air pollution levels in China have experienced dramatic changes over the past couple of decades. In 2016, more than 92% of the world’s population lived in areas experiencing pollution levels exceeding national acceptable limits. Air pollution has become one of the major environmental risks affecting human health and can raise the risk of death, respiratory diseases, and cardiovascular diseases. About three million deaths per year are related to exposure to outdoor air pollution. In particular, fine particulate matter (i.e., PM2.5) has become the fifth leading lethal risk around the world. Long-term exposure to PM2.5 has resulted in 4.2 million deaths, accounting for 7.6% of deaths in 2015 globally and 59% of deaths in eastern and southern Asia, especially China. Since the start of the twentieth century, the Chinese government has implemented a large number of policies to both promote the national economy and improve air quality. Over the years, remote sensing technology has been widely applied in estimating spatially continuous near-surface PM2.5 concentrations. Aerosol optical depth (AOD) products generated from multi-source satellites, e.g., the Moderate-resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS), the Visible infrared Imaging Radiometer (VIIRS), and Himawari-8, have been employed as the most critical independent variable to derive PM2.5 concentrations due to their strongly positive relationships.
research objective: To reveal the spatiotemporal variations of PM2.5, long-term and high-spatial-resolution aerosol optical depths, generated by the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) Multi-Angle implementation of Atmospheric Correction (MAIAC) algorithm, were employed to estimate PM2.5 concentrations at a 1 km resolution using our proposed Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model.
challenges: Traditional physical methods have been used to derive daily PM2.5 concentrations by calculating the fine-mode fraction and correcting for humidity and altitude, but these PM2.5 estimates were poorly correlated with surface measurements.
methods: For this purpose, our proposed tree-based ensemble Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model is adopted here to retrieve PM2.5 concentrations. The 1 km MODIS Multi-Angle implementation of Atmospheric Correction (MAIAC) aerosol product (MCD19A2), newly released in May 2018, is used in this study. Ancillary information on meteorological variables, land use, pollutant emissions, and population are involved in the model to improve PM2.5-AOD relationships. Based on this, we produce for the first time a high-resolution and high-quality PM2.5 dataset for China (i.e., China-HighPM2.5), reconstructing the period from 2000 to 2018. We also perform a comprehensive investigation of spatiotemporal PM2.5 variations across China.
dataset: The resulting PM2.5 dataset for China (i.e., ChinaHighPM2.5) provides the longest record (i.e., 2000 to 2018) at a high spatial resolution of 1 km, enabling the study of PM2.5 variation patterns at different scales.
findings: Our model can capture well variations in PM2.5 concentrations at different spatiotemporal scales, with higher accuracies (i.e., cross-validation coefficient of determination, CV-R2 = 0.86 – 0.90) and stronger predictive powers (i.e., R2 = 0.80 – 0.82) than previously reported. In most places, PM2.5 concentrations showed increasing trends around 2007 and remained high until 2013, after which they declined substantially, thanks to a series of government actions combating air pollution in China. While nationwide PM2.5 concentrations have decreased by 0.89 μg/m3/yr (p < 0.001) during the last two decades, the reduction has accelerated to 4.08 μg/m3/yr (p < 0.001) over the last six years, indicating a significant improvement in air quality. Large improvements occurred in the Pearl and Yangtze River Deltas, while the most polluted region remained the North China Plain, especially in winter.

Verification.Question: Is it possible to achieve a spatial resolution of 1 km for PM2.5 datasets using remote sensing technology?
Does the Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model enhance the accuracy of PM2.5 concentration predictions compared to traditional methods?

Disjunctive.Question: Are traditional physical methods, AI-based models, or hybrid approaches more effective in estimating PM2.5 concentrations from AOD data?
For enhancing PM2.5 datasets, is the incorporation of ancillary information like meteorological variables, land use, or pollutant emissions more crucial?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the methods employed to estimate PM2.5 concentrations at high spatial resolutions?
Where do satellite remote sensing data typically come from when generating spatially continuous PM2.5 datasets?
What challenges are associated with traditional methods of deriving daily PM2.5 concentrations?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to fill spatial gaps in satellite-derived PM2.5 data?
Example.Answer: A method that utilizes artificial intelligence to fill spatial gaps in satellite MODIS MAIAC AOD products was employed, using ancillary data such as ground observations, atmospheric reanalysis, and emission inventories to produce comprehensive PM2.5 data across China.

Example.Question: What is an example of a research approach to improve the accuracy of PM2.5 estimates from satellite data?
Example.Answer: The Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model is an example of a research approach that enhances the accuracy of PM2.5 estimates by using high-resolution MODIS MAIAC aerosol optical depth data along with meteorological variables, land use, pollutant emissions, and population data.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset that provides long-term PM2.5 records at high spatial resolution for a specific region?
Example.Answer: An example is the ChinaHighPM2.5 dataset, which offers a long-term record from 2000 to 2023 at a 1 km spatial resolution, enabling detailed studies of PM2.5 variation patterns across China.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific methods used to fill spatial missing values in satellite-derived data for PM2.5 concentration estimation?
Feature Specification.Answer: artificial intelligence techniques, model data, satellite MODIS MAIAC AOD products, ground-based observations, atmospheric reanalysis, emission inventories

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key factors that contribute to the high spatial resolution of 1 km in a PM2.5 dataset?
Feature Specification.Answer: long-term aerosol optical depths, high-spatial-resolution aerosol optical depths, MODIS Multi-Angle implementation of Atmospheric Correction (MAIAC) algorithm, meteorological variables, land use, pollutant emissions, population data

Feature Specification.Question: What properties are considered to validate the accuracy of PM2.5 concentration models in data collection processes?

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of the data used to estimate PM2.5 concentrations in China?
What is the cross-validation coefficient of determination (CV-R2) range achieved by the model used for PM2.5 data estimation?

Definition.Question: What does 'artificial intelligence technology' mean in the context of data collection for PM2.5 datasets?
Definition.Answer: In the context of data collection for PM2.5 datasets, 'artificial intelligence technology' refers to the use of advanced computational techniques to fill spatial gaps in satellite-derived data, enhance the accuracy of PM2.5 estimates, and integrate various data sources such as ground observations, atmospheric reanalysis, and emission inventories.

Definition.Question: What is the 'Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model' in the context of estimating PM2.5 concentrations?
Definition.Answer: The 'Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model' is a tree-based ensemble approach used to estimate PM2.5 concentrations by leveraging the high-resolution aerosol optical depth data from satellites, along with ancillary information such as meteorological variables and land use, to improve the correlations between PM2.5 and AOD measurements.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for PM2.5 using the Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model compare to traditional physical methods in terms of correlation with surface measurements?
Comparison.Answer: The Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model employs artificial intelligence and satellite data to estimate PM2.5 concentrations, showing higher correlations with surface measurements compared to traditional physical methods, which have shown poor correlation due to humidity and altitude corrections.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the spatial resolution of the ChinaHighPM2.5 dataset differ from other PM2.5 datasets generated through satellite remote sensing?
Comparison.Answer: The ChinaHighPM2.5 dataset provides a high spatial resolution of 1 km, which is finer than many other PM2.5 datasets that typically have coarser resolutions due to limitations in data sources and models.

Interpretation.Question: What can the integration of multi-source satellite data and ground-based observations reveal about the spatial and temporal resolution of air pollution datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of multi-source satellite data, such as MODIS MAIAC AOD products, with ground-based observations, meteorological data, and emission inventories can enhance the spatial and temporal resolution of air pollution datasets, allowing for the production of high-resolution (1 km) and temporally continuous PM2.5 data across large regions like China from 2000 to the present.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of artificial intelligence models improve the accuracy of PM2.5 data collection compared to traditional physical methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Artificial intelligence models, such as the Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model, can improve the accuracy of PM2.5 data collection by effectively capturing variations in PM2.5 concentrations at different spatiotemporal scales, offering cross-validation coefficients and predictive powers superior to those achieved by traditional physical methods.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges do researchers face in developing and maintaining high-quality PM2.5 datasets over extensive time periods, and how can they be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Researchers face challenges such as spatial data gaps in satellite observations and the need to reconcile these with ground measurements and other ancillary data. These challenges can be addressed by using artificial intelligence techniques to fill spatial gaps, combining diverse data sources, and continuously updating datasets to reflect changes in air pollution over time.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of correlating satellite-derived PM2.5 estimates with surface measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Traditional physical methods have been used to derive daily PM2.5 concentrations, but these estimates were poorly correlated with surface measurements due to issues such as fine-mode fraction calculations and corrections for humidity and altitude.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the integration of multiple data sources important for generating high-resolution PM2.5 datasets?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The integration of multiple data sources, including satellite observations, meteorological variables, land use, pollutant emissions, and population data, is critical for improving PM2.5-AOD relationships and producing high-resolution PM2.5 datasets.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes on PM2.5 data accuracy when using artificial intelligence to fill spatial gaps in satellite data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using artificial intelligence to fill spatial gaps in satellite data can result in higher accuracy PM2.5 datasets, as indicated by the ten-fold cross-validation coefficient of determination R2 of 0.92 and a root mean square error (RMSE) of 10.76 µg/m3 in the ChinaHighPM2.5 dataset.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of ground measurements and satellite data affect the spatial resolution of PM2.5 datasets over a long-term period?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating ground measurements with satellite data, such as using the MODIS MAIAC AOD product and other ancillary data, enables the creation of high spatial resolution PM2.5 datasets at a 1 km resolution, allowing for the study of long-term spatiotemporal variations in China, as demonstrated in the ChinaHighPM2.5 dataset.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of employing a tree-based ensemble model on the predictive power and accuracy of PM2.5 concentration estimates?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing a tree-based ensemble model, like the Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model, enhances the predictive power and accuracy of PM2.5 concentration estimates, achieving cross-validation R2 values between 0.86 and 0.90, and predictive R2 values between 0.80 and 0.82, outperforming traditional methods.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the motivation behind employing the Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model for PM2.5 concentration estimation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of using the Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model is to estimate PM2.5 concentrations at a high spatial resolution of 1 km, leveraging the MODIS MAIAC aerosol product and incorporating various ancillary data like meteorological variables, land use, and pollutant emissions to improve PM2.5-AOD relationships.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of reconstructing a high-quality PM2.5 dataset for the period 2000 to 2018?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objective is to produce for the first time a high-resolution and high-quality PM2.5 dataset that captures well variations in PM2.5 concentrations, allowing for a comprehensive investigation of spatiotemporal PM2.5 variations across China and facilitating the evaluation of government actions combating air pollution.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How does the Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model integrate ancillary data to enhance the accuracy of PM2.5 estimations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model incorporates ancillary information such as meteorological variables, land use data, pollutant emissions, and population statistics to strengthen the relationship between PM2.5 and AOD, thus enhancing the accuracy of PM2.5 concentration estimates at a 1 km resolution.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in generating a high-resolution PM2.5 dataset from 2000 to 2018 across China?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves using the MODIS MAIAC AOD product and applying the Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model, which is a tree-based ensemble approach, to estimate PM2.5 concentrations. The model is supported by additional data on meteorological conditions, land use, emissions, and population, resulting in a high-resolution PM2.5 dataset for China covering the period from 2000 to 2018.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the integration of satellite remote sensing with ground-based observations to produce high-resolution PM2.5 datasets in China?
Enablement.Answer: The use of satellite remote sensing, particularly the MODIS MAIAC AOD product, combined with artificial intelligence techniques and large datasets including ground-based observations, atmospheric reanalysis, and emission inventories, has enabled the generation of high-resolution PM2.5 datasets in China.

Enablement.Question: How do the inclusion of meteorological variables, land use, and pollutant emissions enhance the accuracy of PM2.5 concentration estimates in data collection methods?
Enablement.Answer: The inclusion of meteorological variables, land use, and pollutant emissions improves the PM2.5-AOD relationships, enhancing the model's ability to accurately estimate PM2.5 concentrations for high-resolution datasets.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are encountered when using traditional physical methods to derive daily PM2.5 concentrations, and how might newer models overcome these challenges?
Enablement.Answer: Traditional physical methods often result in PM2.5 estimates that poorly correlate with surface measurements, whereas newer models like the Space-Time Extra-Trees (STET) model leverage advanced algorithms and comprehensive datasets to improve accuracy in estimating PM2.5 concentrations.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional physical methods for deriving PM2.5 concentrations not align well with surface measurements?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional physical methods have been used to derive daily PM2.5 concentrations by calculating the fine-mode fraction and correcting for humidity and altitude, but these PM2.5 estimates were poorly correlated with surface measurements.

Expectation.Question: Why might spatially continuous PM2.5 data be challenging to generate using satellite remote sensing techniques?
Expectation.Answer: Satellite remote sensing allows for generating spatially continuous PM2.5 data, but current datasets have overall low accuracies with coarse spatial resolutions limited by data sources and models.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using artificial intelligence techniques to fill spatial gaps in satellite data for creating high-resolution PM2.5 datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Using artificial intelligence techniques to fill spatial gaps in satellite data is considered effective as it has resulted in a high-resolution and high-quality dataset for PM2.5 concentrations across China. The AI-driven approach yields a cross-validation determination coefficient of R2 = 0.92, indicating high accuracy and reliability in the dataset produced.

Judgmental.Question: To what extent do you think the spatial resolution of 1 km is sufficient for capturing detailed spatiotemporal variations in PM2.5 concentrations across China?
Judgmental.Answer: The spatial resolution of 1 km is considered sufficient for capturing detailed spatiotemporal variations in PM2.5 concentrations, as it enables the study of these patterns at different scales. This resolution supports the high accuracy and predictive power required for understanding PM2.5 trends and patterns across diverse regions in China.

Assertion.Question: I can't understand how artificial intelligence techniques can be effectively used to fill spatial gaps in satellite-derived data for air pollution analysis.
Assertion.Answer: Artificial intelligence techniques are used to fill spatial gaps in satellite-derived data by integrating various data sources such as ground observations, atmospheric reanalysis, and emission inventories. This approach allows for the creation of a seamless dataset by using model data to supplement missing satellite information.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in deriving accurate PM2.5 concentration estimates from satellite data.
Assertion.Answer: One of the main challenges in deriving accurate PM2.5 concentration estimates from satellite data is the poor correlation between traditional physical methods and surface measurements. This is due to factors like humidity, altitude, and the fine-mode fraction of aerosols that need to be accounted for, which traditional methods struggle to correct accurately.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the effectiveness of using satellite remote sensing and artificial intelligence techniques to generate high-resolution PM2.5 datasets over large geographical areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Satellite remote sensing and artificial intelligence techniques have been effective in generating high-resolution PM2.5 datasets. By using the MODIS MAIAC AOD product and incorporating artificial intelligence to fill spatial gaps, researchers have produced a seamless near-surface PM2.5 dataset for China with a spatial resolution of 1 km. The dataset's accuracy, with a cross-validation R2 of 0.92 and RMSE of 10.76 µg/m3, suggests that these techniques can accurately capture PM2.5 variations over time and space.
